title: 108_s2361
content: The Act titled "Training and Research in Urology Act of 2004" focuses on research, training, and dissemination of health information related to urologic diseases. The Public Health Service Act is amended to reorganize the Division Director positions for Urologic Diseases, Kidney Diseases, and Hematologic Diseases. The Act aims to support research programs in these areas. The Public Health Service Act is amended to reorganize Division Director positions for Urologic Diseases, Kidney Diseases, and Hematologic Diseases. The Act supports research programs in the diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of various diseases, including diabetes mellitus and endocrine disorders. It also includes training programs in medical schools and clinical trials. It supports research programs in various areas of urologic diseases, including pediatrics, interstitial cystitis, incontinence, stone disease, urinary tract infections, and benign prostatic diseases. $500,000 is authorized for each of fiscal years 2004 and 2005 for the national urologic research plan. The Director of the Institute shall establish the National Urologic Diseases Data System for the collection, storage, analysis, retrieval, and dissemination of data derived from patient populations with urologic diseases. The Public Health Service Act is amended to reorganize Division Director positions for Urologic Diseases, Kidney Diseases, and Hematologic Diseases. It establishes the National Urologic Diseases Information Clearinghouse and strengthens the Urology Interagency Coordinating Committee by encouraging, conducting, or supporting activities in urology research. Authorized appropriations of $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 through 2008 are provided for the Urologic Diseases Interagency Coordinating Committee. The Public Health Service Act is amended to expand O'Brien Urologic Disease Research Centers, with a focus on various aspects of urologic diseases. At least 15 centers will be developed for research in pediatrics, interstitial cystitis, incontinence, stone disease, urinary tract infections, and benign prostatic diseases. Authorization of appropriations is also included. The Public Health Service Act is amended to expand O'Brien Urologic Disease Research Centers, focusing on various aspects of urologic diseases. Authorization of appropriations for the centers is set at $22,500,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008, with additional funding as needed. Technical amendments are made to subsection (c) of the Act, and a subcommittee on Urologic Diseases is established under Section 432. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a subcommittee on urologic diseases and kidney and hematologic diseases. Loan repayment incentives are introduced to encourage urologists and scientists to pursue research careers. Loan repayment program introduced to incentivize urologists and scientists to pursue research careers in urology. The Secretary will establish a program to contract health professionals or scientists for urology research, with the government repaying up to $35,000 of their educational loans annually. Professionals must have significant educational loans relative to income and agree to work for the National Institutes of Health. The program established by the Secretary offers loan repayment of up to $35,000 annually for health professionals or scientists conducting urology research. Participants must have substantial educational loans relative to income and commit to working for the National Institutes of Health or a urology department for at least 3 years. The program follows certain provisions of the National Health Service Corps Loan Repayment Program. Authorization of appropriations for urology research is also included in the amendment. Authorization of appropriations for urology research includes $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008, with additional funding as needed for intra- and interagency activities in urology research.
